Situation1: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story: I sat in the cramped break room, the hum of the vending machine filling the silence as I skimmed the latest pharmacy newsletter. New drugs, new protocols—my mind raced to keep up. As a pharmacist, I was expected to stay sharp, always updated, always ready to answer questions from doctors and patients alike. But my phone buzzed, reminding me of the minor hearing I was due to attend as an advocate. The stakes were low, but my client still deserved my full attention and best representation. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. Should I finish reading about the new anticoagulant, or review my notes for the hearing? Both roles demanded my focus, both had people depending on me. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations, torn between my duty to my profession and my responsibility to my client.
